ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to dissect various arguments, and think critically about them.
I learned how to think logically and critically about hard philosophical writing
Great overview of modern philosophy, better sense for how to write philosophy papers, better ability to break down arguments.

I developed my ability to write analytical essays in philosophy and participate in class discussion. I also developed the ability to draw connections between different philosophers we studied throughout the term.

I think I gained a greater understanding, of course, of the content and history of philosophy. I think the class has also really helped me to understand the structure of an argument in a methodical way. I genuinely believe that this class has altered the way I look at and think about the world; it opened my eyes to certain things that
I had never even considered before.
Learned a lot about philosophy! Learned how to write essays.

In this course, we read the most influential figures of the modern Western philosophical tradition. The chronological order of the readings allowed me to see how each thinker both built upon and challenged the writings which came before them. I was particularly fascinated by the different attempts to resolve the mind-body problem, as well as works that tackled fundamental metaphysical questions, like Kant's Critique of Pure Reason, which has altered my view of the intelligibility of the world. My ability to absorb dense philosophical texts and produce analytical essays on them improved. I also became better at critical thinking and systematically interrogating the validity of an argument.

I learned about philosophers from Descartes to Mill to Kant and more. I also became better at writing papers analyzing philosophy over the course of the semester. The hardest part of the semester for me was learning about Kant's metaphysics so I turned to additional resources to help. The most rewarding part of the class for me was reviewing at the end and being able to compare the different philosophers and their ideas on morality/ethics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the class gives a great range of philosophical texts, and teaches you how to put them in conversation with each other well.
DS Philosophy is great! I feel like I have a solid foundation for any further philosophy courses I might want to take.

Professor Szabo struck a nice balance between direct teaching from slides and discussion, but I found that discussions were best when there was a specific and thought out question (e.g. ship of Theseus) as opposed to when our responses to the slides were solicited.

The course helped me solidify my understanding of texts that were otherwise very difficult, and the in-class discussions were very helpful and engaging. At times I did experience Zoom fatigue due to the online format, though.

I cant think of any weaknesses per se. I think that in general, the class does a good job or teaching a wide range of thinkers in the given time. Perhaps I found it difficult to find some philosophers  mainly Leibniz and Conway  as relevant as others. Other than that, I thought the class was extremely strong.
Very interesting content, very good reading list.

The syllabus is both a strength and weakness of this course. I found all the texts to be interesting and worth reading, but the reading load in conjunction with the other DS courses, particularly when an entire text is assigned instead of sections, can make it difficult to slow down and read more closely, which is of particular importance in philosophy. The recorded lectures are an effective way of introducing a text, while the small seminars are the perfect format for discussing it more in-depth.

Strengths: in my section having very clear presentations helped me comprehend the readings, the lectures were also all very informative and helpful in understanding the readings (the lectures for DS philosophy are the most important to watch out of all the tracks in DS). Additionally, my section's discussions often helped illuminate and explain the nuances and complexities of different authors so I wish I had spoken up more. 
Weaknesses: The readings can get fairly dense and heavy and despite the amount of time we spent with Kant I still felt unsure about some of his writings and ideas. This also may have been on my end or related to the difficulties of the semester, but sometimes I did feel a bit disengaged from understanding the importance behind certain readings or how they could be juxtaposed with other philosophers. Some distinctions were very clearly made (e.g. Conway, Leibniz, and Elizabeth compared to Descartes and the readings on morality/ethics at the end were easily comparable) but I think doing more in class comparison of different philosophers would help with gaining a deeper understanding and memory of the many philosophers we read.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think we made the most of the circumstances.
I thought that the use of screen-shared slides during class was very helpful. At the same time, the online format did sometimes make discussion less fluid.
The philosophy professors of DS were definitely the most technologically adept of all the DS sections. Their lectures were the best! And Professor Szabo made great use of slides as well.
translated very well.

I actually think recorded lectures are superior to live lectures. Although I cannot ask questions during the lecture itself, I enjoy the ability to watch the lecture on my own time and play/pause it as needed. Zoom is obviously not the ideal format for seminar discussions, but it works relatively well and I don't see how it could be improved in any way.
My professor integrated PowerPoints and discussion questions seamlessly into our sections, often with a fitting Calvin and Hobbes sketch, this made the class well structured.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course. I think everyone should have some exposure to philosophy, and this course definitely does so while boosting your critical reasoning.
Yes! Professor Szabo gives amazing paper feedback and is great about explaining things.
Wholeheartedly. One starts to get a better sense of the history of philosophy and the rigor that is expected of you improves your thinking and writing.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student as it was very well-taught and the curriculum was very engaging and relevant to much of the humanities as a whole.

As with any DS class  yes, take it if youre interested in the subject matter and are willing to do the work. In fact, I would probably be more likely to recommend the philosophy track of DS to just about anyone, just because I feel like it teaches such interesting and important skills, and I feel like, of all the tracks, its the one that felt both the most universally essential as well as the most difficult to learn without guidance from a structured class.

I would definitely recommend this course (and all the DS courses) to any student who is interested in receiving a rigorous liberal arts education. I enjoyed philosophy in particular because of how abstract the ideas can be, which I find more intellectually stimulating. Seminars are the ideal format for discussing philosophy, as it allows students to work through their thinking with each other and their professor.

I would recommend this course to a student who is planning to take Directed Studies. Professor Szabo includes fun Calvin and Hobbes sketches and class is well structured. I will say I struggled the most in DS philosophy and I wish I had gone to more office hours to clear up my understanding.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There were also pre-recorded lectures.
weekly recorded lectures
recorded lectures
Recorded lecture and live Zoom seminar
Recorded lecture
Directed Studies philosophy met two times a week for a synchronous, virtual, seminar. Paired with the seminar were weekly recorded lectures on the readings and philosophers for the week.
